title: Global Order in the 21st Century: Learning from Reality
description: The course examines the post-Cold War emerging global order from an international and interdisciplinary perspective. IR theory assuming a world of sovereign states acting in anarchy does not explain present realities. The US became the hegemonic military power while at the same time 122 countries from across the globe, the vast majority of world democracies, reduced their own sovereignty to create an independent and permanent international criminal justice system. Through case studies of various conflicts, we will discover how âunipolar powerâ and such incipient effort to enforce international law coexisted. Topics to be explored include: the complex interaction between sovereign states acting under absolute US military supremacy; the evolution of the UN Security Council practice; the role of regional organizations such as the Arab League, the African Union and the European Union; the demands to control and punish massive crimes; and the impact of the Rome Statute that created the International Criminal Court.
regnotes:
Class meets the first half of the Graduate School spring term on the following Tuesdays: January 13, 20, 27; February 3, 10, 17, 24; March 3.

0.5 GSAS credits
